conclusion: A semi-circular wire frame with a radius of \\( r \\) is formed by connecting wires of the same material and thickness.
The wire frame is fixed in a uniform magnetic field, and the plane of the wire frame is perpendicular to the direction of the magnetic induction intensity.
Points \\( M \\) and \\( N \\) are connected to the two terminals of a direct current constant voltage power supply.
The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the straight part of the wire frame is \\( F \\).
The wire frame consists of a semi-circular arc and a straight line segment.
The plane of the wire frame is perpendicular to the magnetic field.
The straight part of the wire frame experiences a force \\( F \\).
The force on a straight conductor of length \\( L \\) carrying current \\( I \\) in a magnetic field \\( B \\) is given by \\( F = I L B \\).
For the straight part of the wire frame, \\( L = 2r \\), so \\( F = I (2r) B \\).
The force on the semi-circular arc is \\( F_{\text{arc}} = I (\pi r) B \\).
The total force is the vector sum of the forces on the straight and curved parts.
Since both forces are in the same direction, they add up directly.
The total force is \\( F_{\text{total}} = F + F_{\text{arc}} \\).
Substituting the expressions for \\( F \\) and \\( F_{\text{arc}} \\): \\( F_{\text{total}} = I r B (2 + \pi) \\).
We know \\( F = I (2r) B \\), so \\( I r B = \frac{F}{2} \\).
Substitute \\( I r B \\) into the total force equation: \\( F_{\text{total}} = \frac{F}{2} (2 + \pi) \\).
The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the entire wire frame is \\( F_{\text{total}} = F \left(1 + \frac{\pi}{2}\right) \\).
